metadata.title: Application of sulfonated carbon-based catalyst for the furfural production from <ce:small-caps>d</ce:small-caps>-xylose and xylan in a microwave-assisted biphasic reaction

Fig. 1 SEM images of Miscanthus-based material carbonized at 600°C (a) and then sulfonated (b). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Effect of water-CPME volume ratio on dehydration of d-xylose to furfural. Reaction conditions: d-xylose (1.0mmol), SCh (15.0mg), water-CPME, MW, 190°C, 60min. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Effect of reaction temperature on dehydration of d-xylose to furfural. Reaction conditions: d-xylose (1.0mmol), SCh (15.0mg), water-CPME (1:3, mL/mL), MW, 60min. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Effect of reaction time on dehydration of d-xylose to furfural. Reaction conditions: d-xylose (1.0mmol), SCh (15.0mg), water-CPME (1:3, mL/mL), MW, 190°C. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Effect of catalyst (a) and d-xylose (b) loadings on dehydration of d-xylose to furfural. Reaction conditions: d-xylose (0.15g for a) and SCh loading (0.02g for b), water-CPME (1:3, mL/mL), MW, 190°C, 60min. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Reusability of the catalyst. Reaction conditions: d-xylose (0.33mmol), SCh (20mg), water-CPME (1:3, mL/mL), MW, 190°C, 60min. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Effect of reaction temperature on furfural and d-xylose yield from xylan. Reaction conditions: Xylan (0.33mmol based on d-xylose units), SCh (20mg), water-CPME (1:3, mL/mL), MW, 60min. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Effect of reaction time on furfural and d-xylose yield from xylan. Reaction conditions: xylan (0.33mmol based on d-xylose units), SCh (20mg), water-CPME (1:3, mL/mL), MW, 60min. Table 1 Sample BET N C H S O Ash Atomic ratio m2 g−1 Wt% H/C O/C S/C char 7 79.7 79.7 1.91 0.05 6.5 11.0 0.024 0.082 0.001 SCh 317 62.3 62.3 1.72 2.95 31.1 1.34 0.028 0.500 0.047 Application of sulfonated carbon-based catalyst for the furfural production from d-xylose and xylan in a microwave-assisted biphasic reaction Yantao Wang a Frederic Delbecq b Witold Kwapinski c Christophe Len a ⁎ a Sorbonne Universités, Université de Technologie de Compiègne (UTC), CS 60319, 60203 Compiègne Cedex, France Sorbonne Universités Université de Technologie de Compiègne (UTC) CS 60203 Compiègne Cedex 60319 France b Ecole Supérieure de Chimie Organique et Minérale (ESCOM), 1 allée du Réseau Jean-Marie Buckmaster, 60200 Compiègne, France Ecole Supérieure de Chimie Organique et Minérale (ESCOM) 1 allée du Réseau Jean-Marie Buckmaster Compiègne 60200 France c Chemical Sciences Department, Bernal Institute, Faculty of Science and Engineering, University of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland Chemical Sciences Department Bernal Institute Faculty of Science and Engineering University of Limerick Limerick Ireland ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Sulfonated carbon-based catalyst has been prepared, characterized by elemental analysis, SEM, EDX and FTIR and tested as a heterogeneous catalyst in the dehydration of d-xylose and xylan to produce furfural as target compound. With the use of the catalyst the appropriate reaction temperature and time in a mixture of water-CPME (1:3, v/v) were 190°C and 60min, in both cases. In these conditions, dehydration starting from d-xylose and xylan gave 60 and 42% of furfural yields, respectively. The influence of temperature, the residence time and the substrate to catalyst ratios on the d-xylose conversion and furfural selectivity were investigated. Keywords Furfural Biphasic system Heterogeneous catalyst Microwave-assisted dehydration Sulfonated char 1 Introduction Due to the severe decreasing of petroleum resources, many academic and industrial researchers focuse on the development of alternative pathway to access to the twelve top-value added chemicals issued from the transformation of agricultural wastes and woody biomass. Thus, the catalytic conversion of cellulose and hemicellulose rich of lignocellulosic biomass is efficient to generate various organic platform molecules such as furan derivatives and many other compounds. Because hemicellulose and xylan are both polysaccharides, mainly composed of d-xylose sub-units, hydrolysis of the polymer backbone is source of the pentose release in the reaction medium [1]. Especially in acidic condition, this hydrolysis is generally followed by the rapid dehydration of the d-xylose into furfural [2] by loss of three molecules of water. Furfural or “2-furancarboxaldehyde” is useful for the preparation of many small commercial available intermediates such as furoic acid [3], furfuryl alcohol [4] or 2-furonitrile [5] employed for the synthesis of polymeric materials or bioactive compounds. Furfural is also the starting material used for the synthesis of modern organic solvents such as 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (MeTHF) [6], tetrahydrofuran (THF) and also for the elaboration of oil additives. Industrially, furfural is produced by batch and continuous acid hydrolysis of lignocellulosic biomass in a narrow range of temperature found between 170 and 185°C under conventional heating. Immersed in water, the woody precursor is converted using strong mineral acid essentially HCl [7,8], H2SO4 [9], and H3PO4 [10]. Unfortunately, these homogeneous acid catalysts are the main cause of equipment corrosion, high waste streams and increasing treatment costs. To recover the furfural, only distillation was efficient despite the formation of a black carbonaceous side-product called humin, generally observed in an aqueous monophasic system. Humin is overall generated by the cross-polymerization between the just formed furfural and free d-xylose present in solution. Recently, instead of the homogeneous acids, a large variety of heterogeneous catalysts such as sulfonated materials [11–20], HY zeolite [21] or heteropolyacids [22] have demonstrated their potential to dehydrate d-xylose. Humin formation is at the origin of furfural selectivity drop. Two recent strategies are possible to remedy to this problem. First, furfural could be isolated from the previous undesired cross polymerization and from its resinification by adding a non water miscible organic solvent such as cyclopentylmethyl ether (CPME) [23] or methylisobutylketone (MIBK). Our group has already studied different water-CPME biphasic systems including non miscible sulfonated materials such as Nafion NR50 [17] or sulfonated sporopollenin, a very resistant chemically modified biopolymer [18] in presence of NaCl excess. In both cases, catalysts are active at temperature found between 170 and 190°C, and the salt promoted the transfer of the furfural into the organic layer via a salt-out effect. In order to accelerate the d-xylose dehydration, in parallel to the furfural selectivity enhancement, many studies consider microwave irradiation as a great technique to reach this objective and our results obtained in biphasic systems corroborate this idea. In this work, a new sulfonated carbon-based catalyst has successfully demonstrated its capacity to convert d-xylose into furfural in a water-CPME biphasic system under different conditions of time and temperature. The catalyst reusability was proven and its morphology was studied by SEM, EDX and FTIR at different stages of this study. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Furfural (99% minimum) and D(+)-xylose were purchased from Acros Organic. Cyclopentylmethyl ether was supplied by Sigma Aldrich. Xylan (from benchwood >90% (HPLC)) was obtained from Sigma Life Sciences. The water used in all experiments was a Millipore Milli-Q grade. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Miscanthus x giganteus was the source of biomass for the production of char by carbonization in the process of slow pyrolysis. This form of pyrolysis utilizes a long vapor residence time in order to maximize char yields. Char was produced in tubular furnace at temperature of 600°C. To achieve anaerobic conditions, a nitrogen pressure of 1.6atm was maintained in the reactor. Once the char were collected, they were ground and sieved between 180 and 600 mm and underwent sulfonation. In order to produce the catalytic acid materials, 20.0g of char was placed in a 500mL flask with 200mL of concentrated (95–97%) sulfuric acid. The mixtures were heated at 150°C for 24h on magnetic hotplate stirrers, fitted with J-type PTFE coated thermocouples. The slurries were then filtered and washed several times with distilled water until the pH became neutral, and sulfonated char based catalyst (SCh) was obtained [24]. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen and sulphur were analysed with an Elemental Vario EL Cube. The analysis was conducted according to BS EN 15104 (2011). Sulphanilamide was used as a standard. Oxygen was calculated by difference, subtracting the percentage of C, H, N, S and ash from 100%. SEM (Scanning Electron Microscopy)-EDX (Energy Dispersive X-ray Diffraction) analysis of native and sulfonated char (SCh) at different stage of the experiments was performed on a Hitachi SU-70 equipped with a microanalysis detector for EDX. SEM micrographs acquired in secondary electron mode were obtained at low vacuum, 20kV of accelerating voltage with a 10mm working distance. EDX spectra were collected at 30° angle, 15kV accelerating. INCA software was used to examine the energy spectrum in order to determine the abundance of specific elements and to give an overall view of the composition of the samples. FTIR spectra were recorded on a Agilent Technologies Cary 630 instrument in the range of 4000–650cm−1. XRD experiments were recorded on a PanAnalytic/Philips X’pert MRD diffractometer (40kV, 35mA) using Cu Κa (λ=0.15418nm) radiation. Scans were performed over a 2θ range from 10 to 80, at step size of 0.018° with a counting time per step of 5s. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) nitrogen adsorption measurements were carried out at 77K using an Micrometrics Gemini 236 volumetric adsorption analyzer. The samples were outgassed for 12h at 200°C under vacuum (po 10−2 Pa) and subsequently analysed. The linear part of the BET equation (relative pressure between 0.05 and 0.30) was used for the determination of the specific surface area. 2.4 General procedure for the synthesis of furfural in water-CPME as biphasic media from d-xylose and xylan In a typical experiment, 0.15g (1.0mmol) of D(+)-xylose and 15.0mg of sulfonated char based catalyst (SCh) were introduced in a 10mL vial closed with a septum, followed by the addition of water (1mL) and CPME (3mL). Biphasic batch reactions were carried out by way of microwave heating apparatus (AntonPaar Monowave 300) and stirred under magnetic stirring (600rpm) for the desired time. Temperature in the reaction vessel was measured by means of an IR sensor and the vial was pressurized due to the normal vapor pressure of the solution at defined reaction temperature. At the end of the reaction, each sample was diluted with acetonitrile to obtain 100mL of diluted solution and filtered prior to analysis through a syringe filter (PTFE, 0.45μm, VWR). Identical procedure was done starting from 0.15g of xylan. 2.5 Product analysis Each sample of the reaction mixture was analyzed separately by means of a Shimadzu Prominence HPLC. D-Xylose was detected with a low temperature evaporative light scattering detector (ELSD-LTII) and products were detected with a UV–vis detector (SPD-M20A) at a wavelength of 275nm. The column used was a Grace C18 column (250×4.6mm 5μm). The mobile phase was MeOH–H2O (90:10) solution flowing at rate of 0.5mLmin−1. The column oven was set at 40°C. Regularly, the calibration was checked out in order to avoid eventual experimental errors associated with all measurements reported below. d-Xylose conversion (X), furfural yield (Yi) and furfural selectivity (Si) were calculated by the following equations: X = ( I n i t i a l x y l o s e a m o u n t ( m o l ) − F i n a l x y l o s e a m o u n t ( m o l ) ) I n i t i a l x y l o s e a m o u n t ( m o l ) × 100 Y i = F i n a l f u r f u r a l a m o u n t ( m o l ) I n i t i a l x y l o s e a m o u n t ( m o l ) × 100 S i = F u r f u r a l y i e l d C o n v e r s i o n o f x y l o s e × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation, structure and morphology analysis of the catalyst Elemental composition and ash content for Miscanthus based char made at 600°C and for the sulfonated char are presented in Table 1 . The direct sulfonation of char by the concentrated sulfuric acid leads to the production of its sulfonated counterparts proved by both increases sulfur atom and oxygen atom percentages recorded during the elementar analysis. BET experiment showed that surface for the char was only 7m2 g−1, and sulfonation process led to increase of the surface area to 317m2 g−1, probably due to the harsh conditions capable of breaking exfolating the successive carbon layers. Visual observation was performed by SEM to assess the materials morphology throughout the production process. There was no visible difference between untreated chars and the SCh catalyst. Catalyst material presented the same inner, well developed, honeycomb structure with a highly complex network of pores, channels and fibrous ridged surfaces (Fig. 1 ). All materials collected at each stage of the catalyst preparation were also analysed using the energy-dispersive (EDX) detector integrated into the SEM. Spectra of the catalyst showed the presence of sulfur due to sulfonation in association withslight traces of silica, (see ESI, Fig. S1). Besides, FT-IR measurements were carried out to obtain an understanding of chemical changes of the surface during the catalyst production. When carbonization occured, the biomass is degraded and rearranged producing phenolic and polyaromatic rings. Some of these functional groups such as aromatic rings will then undergo sulfonation reactions with sulfuric acid introducing sulfonic groups on the surface of the catalyst. Both spectra of Miscanthus based materials (see ESI Fig. S2) show the presence of aromatic combination band at around 2117cm−1 persisting throughout sulfonation. The CO stretching found at 1644cm−1 is attributable to the carbonyl group, while the peak at 1600cm−1 is characteristic of the CC aromatic ring stretch of large polyaromatic structures. A signal located at 917cm−1 also confirmed the existence of simple CH bonds inside the material. Vibration bands of SCh observed at 1169 and 1022cm−1 could be assigned to the OSO stretching vibration group and indicated the presence of SO3H groups on the catalyst [25]. Then, XRD patterns of Miscanthus-based char was rich in crystalline structures as presented in Fig. S3 of the ESI proven by broad C (002) diffraction peaks in native char sample between 2θ=15–30° and another broad and weak C (101) diffraction peaks between 2θ=40–50° indicating the presence of an amorphous solid carbon structure. However, through the sulfonation process, any crystalline structures remained intact and the SCh became amorphous confirmed by the suppression of the previous signal. 3.2 Effect of volume ratio for the production of furfural CPME is considered as a promising green co-solvent to extract furfural formed in aqueous phase in order to prevent this material of its undesired degradation. Thus, the volume of CPME has also a great influence on the produced furfural yield. To confirm this hypothesis, the influence of water-CPME volume ratio on the production of furfural was determined at 190°C for 60min under microwave irradiation using different volume ratios, and the initial SCh loading was set as 10wt% of d-xylose (1.0mmol). d-Xylose conversion and furfural yield reached 87% and 37% respectively in sole water (Fig. 2 ). In a biphasic system, d-xylose conversion, furfural yield and selectivity increased with the addition of CPME to the detriment of water content, and the maximum values of 60% and 62% were reached for the furfural yield and its selectivity respectively for a system composed of 1mL water and 3mL of CPME. By increasing the volume of CPME, after the reaction, the d-xylose almost disappeared, however, furfural yield and selectivity slightly decreased together. Simultaneously, more humin was observed after the reaction meaning that the second type of side-reactions or resinification of furfural itself was promoted in the organic layer. It is also possible to imagine that furfural formed in water phase can react with d-xylose to form hydroxyl groups holding carbonaceous material and water-soluble side-products in the remaining small volume of water. These experiments showed that the best water-CPME ratio (1:3, v/v) was kept for this catalyst and this ratio was set up for the dehydration of d-xylose to furfural in the whole study. 3.3 Effect of reaction temperature for the production of furfural It is well-known that reaction temperature has effectively a crucial effect on the dehydration process. Therefore, reaction temperature ranged from 150°C to 210°C for 60min under microwave irradiation in batch was investigated (Fig. 3 ). At a temperature lower than 180°C, d-xylose conversion can become superior to 77%, however the furfural yield and selectivity were both limited. In fact, at the lower temperatures, the catalyst has the ability to dehydrate partially the d-xylose into various intermediates, thus the reaction is surely not complete. With the increase of reaction temperature from 150°C to 190°C, the furfural yield, the selectivity and the d-xylose conversion increased to 60%, 62% and 97% respectively. At 210°C, furfural yield and selectivity were similar (59%) but at higher temperature furfural has a poor stability and will quickly react to furnish the dark brown humin. In our case, the more relevant reaction temperature was detected at 190°C. This condition afforded the best furfural yield and selectivity. 3.4 Effect of reaction time for the production of furfural The variation of residence time from 10 to 60min at 190°C was investigated in order to identify the most favorable residence time. d-Xylose conversion, furfural yield and selectivity gradually increased with the time extension (Fig. 4 ). d-Xylose could be converted in a very short time. Only 10min are enough to obtain 28% of selectivity which rapidly increased after 30min, and it tended to be invariable. Here, the maximum of furfural yield and selectivity at 190°C gave the values of 60% and 62%, respectively when the reaction was carried out for 60min. It should be important to notice that furfural content decreased by 7% without catalyst at 190°C for 60min even taken in the best current water-CPME (1:3, v/v) biphasic system, due to the induced acidic character of water in subcritical condition, mainly caused by the resinification of produced furfural. 3.5 Effect of catalyst and substrate loading for the production of furfural The effect of the initial catalyst (from 0 to 25mg) and d-xylose (varying from 0.05g to 0.25g) loadings in a mixture of water-CPME (1:3, v/v) was also studied at 190 °C for 60min (Fig. 5 ). The concentration of catalyst can significantly affect d-xylose conversion and furfural yield (Fig. 5a). d-Xylose cannot be sufficiently consumed when catalyst concentration is lower than 10% but higher catalyst concentration did not cause higher furfural yield, the medium become too acidic. To investigate the behavior of the catalyst, one experiment with furfural as substrate was tested at 190°C for 60min in presence of 15.0mg of the catalyst immersed in the most suitable volume ratio. The results proved that 15% of furfural content decreased, but only 7% (two times lower) of the compound disappeared when the catalyst was not added to the medium. This result indicated that an excess of catalyst loading could be the main cause of furfural loss. The degradation occurring here could be also explained by the nature and three-dimensional structure of this catalyst. Once the furfural is adsorbed on the surface, it could easily react to form the humin on the catalyst periphery. D-Xylose conversion was quite complete when its loading was inferior to 150mg (Fig. 5b). In that situation, furfural yield and selectivity slightly increased to 64% in parallel to the d-xylose loading drop to 50mg. Therefore, the optimized initial loading was set up at 20mg of catalyst and 50mg (0.33mmol) of d-xylose respectively. 3.6 Effect of catalyst recovery for the production of furfural Recycling performance is a significant index to evaluate the performance of a catalyst. In our case, ten cycles of experiments were studied under optimized conditions to estimate the properties of recovered catalyst (as shown in Fig. 6 ). In this work, the organic CPME phase containing the furfural was separated from the reaction medium after each catalytic run. Then, d-xylose (50.0mg) and fresh CPME (3mL) were added to the recycled aqueous phase, containing the original catalyst without being subjected to further treatment before starting the next cycle. Interestingly, after one cycle, only 1.2% of sulfate traces were detected by Inductivity Coupled Plasma (ICP) analysis in the reaction medium, especially in the aqueous layer. Up to ten cycles, furfural yield containing in CPME phase gave an average value of 60% for all cycles, which means that the catalyst has stable and excellent capacity to dehydrate d-xylose into furfural in biphasic system under microwave irradiation. 3.7 Furfural production from xylan To extend this study into lignocellulosic biomass for the production of furfural, experiments with xylan as a suitable model were carried out under the optimized method as follow: xylan (0.33mmol based on d-xylose units), sulfonated catalyst (20mg), water-CPME (1:3, mL/mL), MW, 190°C, 60min, and furfural yield reached 37%. This poorer furfural yield was attributed to the two-steps reaction mechanism: a) hydrolysis of xylan into d-xylose (1 step in several steps); b) dehydration of d-xylose into furfural (3 steps). For this reason, variation of reaction temperature from 160°C to 210°C for 60min (Fig. 7 ) and reaction time from 10min to 90min at 190°C (Fig. 7) have been developed to optimize furfural yield from xylan. At 170°C, 22% of d-xylose was yielded after 60min under microwave irradiation, however, only 13% of furfural was produced, which means that the temperature is not sufficient for the formation of furfural but enough to hydrolyze xylan into monomers and oligomers sub-unit (Fig. 7). The higher furfural yield of 37% was obtained at 190°C for 60min, and 8% of d-xylose was remained after reaction. Despite of reaction temperature increasing to become superior to 200°C, furfural yield was not improved. In fact, even if SCh expressed high porosity, due to its high polymerization degree of the biopolymer, the reaction was limited to the accessible sulfonated surface of SCh and cannot occur inside the cavities of the catalyst. However, furfural yield slightly decreased owing to the occurrence of side-reactions. At 190°C, furfural was quickly formed, simultaneously, d-xylose formed from xylan was rapidly consumed in 40min, and a maximal furfural yield of 42% was obtained after heating for 80min and then remained almost constant for up to 90min (Fig. 8 ). In regards to these results, the optimized formation of furfural from xylan was obtained at 190°C for 80min upon microwave irradiation in the presence of 20wt% of catalyst in water-CPME (1:3, v/v) biphasic system. 4 Conclusion In summary, this work reports a new efficient process using heterogeneous sulfonated catalyst coming from Miscanthus x giganteus for the production of furfural from d-xylose in 60% yield. This new promising bio-based acidic catalyst was fully characterized using elemental analysis, SEM, EDX and FTIR spectroscopy. Its activity and recyclability in a water-CPME biphasic system under microwave irradiation in batch put it as a potent candidates to replace the conventional homogeneous acid catalysts such as sulfuric acid. This material is currently studied in our laboratory for realizing other chemical transformations. Acknowledgements YW would like to thank the China Scholarship Council (CSC) for the financial support. This work was performed, in partnership with the COST Action FP 1306 Valorisation of ligno-cellulosic biomass strams for sustainable production of chemicals, materials and fuels using low environmental impact technologies. coredata.dc:description: Sulfonated carbon-based catalyst has been prepared, characterized by elemental analysis, SEM, EDX and FTIR and tested as a heterogeneous catalyst in the dehydration of d-xylose and xylan to produce furfural as target compound. With the use of the catalyst the appropriate reaction temperature and time in a mixture of water-CPME (1:3, v/v) were 190°C and 60min, in both cases. In these conditions, dehydration starting from d-xylose and xylan gave 60 and 42% of furfural yields, respectively. The influence of temperature, the residence time and the substrate to catalyst ratios on the d-xylose conversion and furfural selectivity were investigated.
coredata.dc:title: Application of sulfonated carbon-based catalyst for the furfural production from d-xylose and xylan in a microwave-assisted biphasic reaction
